The Quillen-Suslin theorem asserts that every finitely-generated projective module over a polynomial ring R=k[x1,…,xn]R=k[x_1,…,x_n]R=k[x1​,…,xn​] for kkk a field (or a PID), is free.

Is the theorem false if we replace RRR by k[xi,i∈N]k[x_i, i \in \mathbb{N}]k[xi​,i∈N]? I’m sure it should be the case but I don’t know a lot about these matters…
I have no intuition for that. So you're looking for a summand of a finitely generated free module of k[x1,x2,… ]k[x_1, x_2, \dots]k[x1​,x2​,…] that's not itself free.

Let me think two minutes. I'm looking for a finitely-generated projective module MMM over k[x1,x2,...]k[x_1,x_2,...]k[x1​,x2​,...] which is not free ie.:

  • MMM is a k[x1,x2,...]k[x_1,x_2,...]k[x1​,x2​,...]-module
  • MMM is not free
  • Finitely-generated: M=k[x1,x2,...].m1+...+k[x1,x2,...].mpM= k[x1,x_2,...].m_1 + ... + k[x1,x_2,...].m_pM=k[x1,x2​,...].m1​+...+k[x1,x2​,...].mp​ for some elements m1,...,mp∈Mm_1,...,m_p \in Mm1​,...,mp​∈M
  • Projective: M⊕QM \oplus QM⊕Q is free for some k[x1,x2,...]k[x_1,x_2,...]k[x1​,x2​,...]-module QQQ
Yes, I'm looking for one which is finitely-generated

I think that every finitely-generated submodule of k[x1,x2,...]k[x_1,x_2,...]k[x1​,x2​,...] is a finitely-generated submodule of some k[xI]k[x_I]k[xI​] for a finite set of variables III. It might help if it is true.
(Maybe the theorem is true as an easy consequence of Quillen-Suslin in some way like this.)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Yes, I'm looking for one which is finitely-generated

Maybe it is equivalent to look for any summand and this is why you didn't mention finitely-generated?

No, I just left out that condition by accident. I stuck it back in. For all I know there might be non-finitely-generated modules of k[x1,…,xn]k[x_1, \dots, x_n]k[x1​,…,xn​] that are projective but not free! I imagine that the assumption was put in for a good reason.
Ahah ok. This is why I think it's probably false indeed.
Hmm, I was thinking about the assumption "polynomial ring with finitely many variables": the finite number of variables is probably here for a reason

John Baez said:

So you're looking for a summand of a finitely generated free module of k[x1,x2,… ]k[x_1, x_2, \dots]k[x1​,x2​,…] that's not itself free.

I think it's still not that, no :sweat_smile: ?
Yes, the summand must be finitely generated but not necessarily the free module

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

(Maybe the theorem is true as an easy consequence of Quillen-Suslin in some way like this.)

Yes, I think this is what happens. To see this, for a fg projective module PPP, consider the composite

Rn≅P⊕Q→P→P⊕Q≅Rn,R^n \cong P \oplus Q \to P \to P \oplus Q \cong R^n ,Rn≅P⊕Q→P→P⊕Q≅Rn,

where all maps are the obvious ones. Then this map can be represented by a matrix e∈Mn×n(R)e \in M_{n \times n}(R)e∈Mn×n​(R) with e2=ee^2 = ee2=e. The module is free if and only if there is an isomorphism P≅RmP \cong R^mP≅Rm for some mmm, and using this we can also represent the projection P⊕Q→PP \oplus Q \to PP⊕Q→P as a matrix p∈Mn×m(R)p \in M_{n \times m}(R)p∈Mn×m​(R), and the inclusion P→P⊕QP \to P \oplus QP→P⊕Q as a matrix i∈Mm×n(R)i \in M_{m \times n}(R)i∈Mm×n​(R), such that e=ipe = ipe=ip and pi=1pi = 1pi=1. Like this, I believe that we get the following:

Theorem: A ring RRR has the property that every fg projective module is free if and only if every idempotent matrix with entries from RRR splits.

Now the punchline: over R=k[x1,x2,… ]R = k[x_1,x_2,\dots]R=k[x1​,x2​,…], every matrix can only contain finitely many variables! Like this, the problem is reduced to the Quillen-Suslin theorem, and it should indeed be true that every fg projective module is free. I'm saying "should" because I haven't carefully worked out the proof of the above theorem. But assuming that it's true, we can think of this geometrically as saying that every algebraic vector bundle in infinite dimensions can vary in only finitely many of them, and it's trivially trivial in the other directions.

Thank you! I will try to understand your theorem better a bit later. But for now, I think if it works, it works also for R=k[xi, i∈I]R=k[x_i,~i \in I]R=k[xi​, i∈I] for any set III. In fact I'm interested by these rings also. The reason is that I wanted to understand if we can replace RRR by the symmetric algebra of any vector space over field (which is isomorphic to a k[xi, i∈I]k[x_i,~i \in I]k[xi​, i∈I]).
Yes, it should work for any III regardless of cardinality.

In general, if P(R)\mathbf{P}(R)P(R) is the monoid of finitely generated projective RRR-modules, up to isomorphism,
then P\mathbf{P}P preserves filtered colimits, see here, 2.1.6.
In our situation, k[xi,i∈I]k[x_i, i \in I]k[xi​,i∈I] is the filtered colimit of the k[xi,i∈J]k[x_i, i \in J]k[xi​,i∈J] for JJJ going over the finite subsets of III.
And P(k[xi,i∈J])\mathbf{P}(k[x_i, i \in J])P(k[xi​,i∈J]) is always the monoid (N,+)(\mathbb{N},+)(N,+), so it is still this monoid of natural numbers in the limit.
